title: Lung Illnesses Linked to Vaping Rise, Says CDC
text:
Federal health officials warned the public on Friday not to buy e-cigarette products off the street or modify products that they already own, as the number of people who have developed severe lung illnesses after vaping significantly increased in the past week.

As of Aug. 27, there have been 215 reported illnesses across 25 states in the past several months, with more cases being investigated, according to the CDC. The new number is an increase of 62 cases from last week, when the CDC issued a statement about the investigation into the illnesses.

Patients, mostly teenagers and young adults, often first report symptoms like breathing difficulty, coughing, chest pain and fatigue, officials said, which gradually grow worse and have resulted in hospitalization. Some patients also experienced diarrhea and vomiting.

Many patients needed assisted ventilation, and some had to be intubated, according to the CDC, and one adult in Illinois died after being hospitalized for severe respiratory problems linked to recent e-cigarette use.

Why people are developing these severe illnesses is still unknown, but officials suspect that there is a connection to vaping, without linking the illnesses to a specific product. So far, the Food and Drug Administration has received roughly 80 samples of involved products for analysis, though many of those samples were missing complete information, according to the new statement.

E-cigarettes usually contain nicotine, flavorings and other chemicals. Many e-cigarettes also contain substances such as tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), a compound in marijuana, and cannabinoids.

The use of THC and cannabinoids was reported in many of the cases. But there is no one product involved in all of the cases, and there aren’t any specific products in e-cigarettes that are currently known to cause respiratory illnesses, officials said.

“We are working closely with state and local health officials to investigate these incidents as quickly as possible,” federal officials said in the statement. “We are committed to taking appropriate actions as a clearer picture of the facts emerges.”

In addition to providing updates about the investigation, the CDC also issued a Health Alert Network Health Advisory, noting that people should consider halting their use of e-cigarettes while the investigation is continuing, if they are concerned about the respiratory health risks.

It also says that teenagers, young adults, pregnant women and adults who don’t already use tobacco products shouldn’t start using e-cigarettes, and people who do should closely monitor their own health.

The American Lung Association responded to the CDC health alert, calling on the federal government to give a clearer message and warn the public not to vape or use e-cigarettes.

Gregory Conley, president of the American Vaping Association, which advocates for the vaping industry, agrees that consumers should stay away from street-bought products, saying that “black market” products with THC are playing a “clear role” in the illnesses.

“The CDC and the FDA should be working to assure adult smokers and ex-smoker vapers that legally purchased nicotine vaping products remain a better alternative to cigarettes,” said Mr. Conley.
description: Federal health officials warned the public not to buy e-cigarette products off the street or modify products they already own, as the number of people who have developed severe lung illnesses after vaping jumped in the past week.
